isis.stitle: ANTILOCK AIR BRAKE SYSTEM: BENDIX - TROUBLESHOOTING - EC-15 DIAGNOSTIC STEPS

svcsubproc.title: Initial Start-Up Self Test Procedure
svcsubproc.para: For a vehicle without any system defects, the following information describes "normal behavior" during the engine start-up.

note.para: The EC-15 will begin start-up diagnostics when the key is turned to the ON position. However, when the starter is engaged, the crank relay cuts power to the EC-15 during the engine cranking process. When the engine cranking process is ended, power is re-applied to the EC-15 and the "Initial Start-up Procedure" will start over.

svcsubproc.title: Initial Start-Up Self Test Procedure: Normal Start-Up
svcsubproc.para: Test Explanation - Each M-21 modulator contains (1) exhaust solenoid and (1) hold solenoid. During this test with service brakes applied, the EC-15 controller will "fire" or energize each solenoid briefly in a test cycle making a "chuff" sound as the air exhausts. The exhaust solenoid will be "fired" for 10 milli-seconds, then a pause for only a few milli-seconds and the hold solenoid will "fire" for 20 milli-seconds. The two firing in rapid sequence produces a single "chuff" sound. If the solenoids are wired incorrectly, or if only one is firing, the sound will be distinctly different. The EC-15 will begin at the right front, then go to the left front, then the right rear, and finish the cycle on the left rear. It will then repeat the cycle, making two complete cycles. The second cycle is a repeat of the first.

When the vehicle engine is started (or key switch turned to ON position), the EC-15 first runs a series of modulator tests as described in the preceding paragraph. The controller begins at the right front M-21 modulator and fires each of the (2) solenoids contained in the modulator, then moves to the left front modulator and fires each of the (2) solenoids in that modulator and moves to the right rear modulator, again firing both solenoids, and finally moves to the left rear and fires each of the (2) solenoids in that modulator. The cycle will be repeated one more time, in the same sequence.

After the modulator test is complete, the EC-15 will next energize the "Engine Brake Relay" five or six times rapidly, causing a "chattering sound" from the relay (if vehicle is equipped with engine brake), then the yellow instrument panel warning light will flash twice and then remain on until the vehicle speed is increased to at least 7-10 mph for several seconds, then the warning light will "go out."
This behavior indicates the antilock system is performing correctly. The EC-15 will continue to monitor system performance and illuminate the warning light if a problem is detected.

note.para: If the vehicle is warm, and shut-off briefly, then restarted and quickly driven past the seven-to-ten miles-per-hour point, the system may not go through the diagnosis process of flashing twice, then staying on until the seven miles per hour is attained.

svcsubproc.title: Initial Start-Up Self Test Procedure: Start-Up With Defect In System
svcsubproc.para: If the system is started and the instrument panel antilock warning light does not perform as described above, a system fault is present. The warning light:

item.para: May not illuminate on at all
Or may illuminate (but not flash twice) and stay on
Or may flash twice and illuminate, then after seven to ten miles per hour is reached, remain illuminated or blink intermittently.

svcsubproc.para: Any of the preceding actions indicate that the EC-15 has detected a fault in the system. Perform DIAGNOSING THE INITIAL START-UP TEST PROCEDURE.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing The Initial Start-Up Test Procedure
svcsubproc.para: If the "Initial Start-up Procedure" is performed in a quiet area, and if the technician listens carefully, certain activities are accompanied by a particular sound that can assist in diagnosing the problem.

step1.para: Turn the vehicle ignition to the ON or RUN position (do not start) and listen for "specific sounds" made by the ABS components (relays and solenoids), then observe the action of the antilock yellow warning light located on the instrument panel. Go to step 2.

When the key is turned ON, the CR-15 will begin a series of tests on the modulators. First, note if the RIGHT FRONT modulator "fires," making a click sound or a "chuff" sound if the service brake air is applied.

step2.para: If the sound was not present, it indicates that the modulator failed to "fire." Note the defect and go on to step 3.
If the sound was noted, go on to step 3.

step1.para: Note if the LEFT FRONT modulator "fires" making a "click" sound or a "chuff" sound if service brake air is applied.

step2.para: If the sound was not noted, it indicates that the modulator failed to "fire." Note the defect and go on to step 4.
If the sound was noted, go on to step 4.

step1.para: Note if the RIGHT REAR modulator "fires" making a "click" sound or a "chuff" sound if service brake air is applied.

step2.para: If the sound was not noted, it indicates that the modulator failed to "fire." Note the defect and go on to step 5.
If the sound was noted, go on to step 5.

step1.para: Note if the LEFT REAR modulator "fires" making a "click" sound or a "chuff" sound if service brake air is applied.

step2.para: If the sound was not noted, it indicates that the modulator failed to "fire." Note the defect and go on to step 6.
If the sound was noted, go on to step 6.

step1.para: Steps 2 through 5 are repeated one time (The EC-15 repeats the same test cycle one additional time).
Also at this time, if the vehicle is equipped with an engine brake, you can hear (or feel) the engine brake relay "chatter."

step2.para: If sound (chattering) was not present, it indicates that the relay system may be defective. Note the defect and go on to step 8.
If the sound was present, go to step 8.

step1.para: At this point, the antilock warning light should flash twice, then illuminate and remain illuminated. At the same time the warning light flashes, you can hear the warning light relay "de-energize." It will make a "click" each time the light illuminates. If the relay does not "de-energize," the light will not flash. Note dash light activity.

step2.para: If the dash light does NOT ILLUMINATE AT ALL, stop here and proceed to DASH LIGHT TESTING.
If the dash light FAILS to flash twice before illuminating, stop here and proceed to " INSPECT FOR ILLUMINATED LEDs - 1."
If the dash light flashed twice before illuminating and staying on, proceed to step 9.

step1.para: If the dash light DID FLASH TWICE and REMAIN ON, start the engine. Starting the engine will cause the EC-15 to reset and begin the "Initial Start-up Procedure" over again. Verify that the original start-up sequence of events that occurred with the key ON are repeated.

step2.para: If the key-on cycle of events is not the same, rerun this test.
If the cycle is repeated, then go to step 10.

step1.para: Increase vehicle speed to above 10 MPH for several seconds and observe the dash light.

step2.para: If the dash light REMAINS ILLUMINATED, proceed to " INSPECTION FOR ILLUMINATED LEDs-2."

If the dash light GOES OUT after vehicle speed reaches 7-10 miles per hour, the system is functioning normally. Make notes of the parts replaced or repaired and all steps taken on the Troubleshooting Sheet.

svcsubproc.title: Diagnosing the Initial Start-Up Procedure with Defect in the Antilock System
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 15, Figure 16, and Figure 17.

figure.caption: Figure 15. Diagnosing the Initial Start-Up Procedure With Defect in the Antilock System (Part 1)
Figure 16. Diagnosing the Initial Start-Up Procedure With Defect in the Antilock System (Part 2)
Figure 17. Diagnosing the Initial Start-Up Procedure With Defect in the Antilock System (Part 3)

svcsubproc.title: Dash Light Testing
svcsubproc.para: This test is performed when the warning light fails to illuminate during the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

important.para: This test is for the 96/9700 and 93/9400 models only. References to a particular connector, circuit, etc., by number will be made for the 96/9700 models, with the 93/9400 model reference number in parentheses, if the number is different than the 96/9700 number. For example: "Disconnect harness connector C355 (or C288)...." The C355 refers to 96/9700 models and the C288 refers to the 93/9400 models.

step1.para: Before beginning this procedure, turn ignition key to the ON position, and check the EC-15 LEDs. Record on the Troubleshooting Record Sheet the condition of LEDs and action of the dash light. Turn key switch OFF. Note all test steps in the Troubleshooting Record Sheet.
Check condition of: the yellow warning light bulb located on instrument panel, and the 15A fuse, S18 (or 20A fuse, F4).

step2.para: If the bulb is defective, replace and rerun the "Initial Start-up Procedure." If the fuse is defective, locate the cause for the overload condition and repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If the bulb and/or fuse are not defective, go to the Step 3.

note.para: Next step will cause several LEDs to illuminate. Later, clearing of all illuminated LEDs will be required. Be sure that any LEDs illuminated were noted in step 1.

step1.para: In this step we will open the ground circuit from the warning light relay to the EC-15 controller. This will cause the light to illuminate, if the warning light and relay circuits are not defective. With the key OFF, disconnect C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 harness connector. Turn the key switch ON, and note the yellow warning light on the instrument panel.

step2.para: If the warning light is now illuminated, it indicates the EC-15 is defective. Replace the EC-15 controller. Rerun the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If the yellow warning light does not illuminate, DO NOT reconnect the harness to the EC-15 at this time, but go to step 4.

step1.para: Remove the warning light relay from the wire harness connector C361 (or C285), and turn the key switch ON. Install jumper from harness connector circuit 94E to vehicle ground. The warning light should illuminate.

step2.para: If the warning light does not illuminate, locate the open in the warning light circuit between C361 (or C285) and fuse S18 (or F4). Also verify power from the fuse. Repair the defect, then run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If the warning light illuminates, go to step 5.

step1.para: With the warning light relay removed from C361 (or C285) harness connector and the key switch ON, check voltage to ground at the relay harness connector, circuit 94B/94C.

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, locate the open in the feed circuit 94B/94D to fuse S18 (or F4). Repair the circuit, then go to step 6.
If voltage is present, go to step 6.

step1.para: With the warning light relay removed from harness connector C361 (or C285), turn the switch key OFF. Use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at harness connector circuit 94-G. Continuity should be present.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, locate the open in circuit 94-G to ground and repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If continuity to ground is present, go to step 7.

step1.para: Connector C355 (or C288) was previously disconnected from the EC-15 harness in step 2. With the warning light relay removed from the harness connector C361 (or C285), and the key OFF, use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at harness connector circuit 94H. The circuit should not have continuity to ground, because C355 (96/9700) or C288 (93/9400) is disconnected from the EC-15 harness.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is present in circuit 94H, locate the short to ground and repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If continuity to ground is not present at circuit 94H, go to step 8.

step1.para: With the warning light relay removed from relay harness connector C361 (or C285), install a jumper between the warning light relay connector terminals for circuit 94-G and 94H. (Terminal 3 to terminal 5 as shown in the circuit diagram.) At the chassis antilock harness connector C355 (or C288) use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at circuit 94H (pin K).

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, locate the open in the circuit and repair. Go to step 9.
If continuity to ground is present, go to step 9.

step1.para: Remove jumper installed in step 8, and re-install warning light relay. Do not reconnect C355 (or C288) to EC-15 harness. Turn key ON and note condition of warning lamp.

step2.para: If warning light is illuminated, turn key OFF. Re-connect C355 (or C288) to EC-15 harness and use magnet to reset LEDs. Run "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If the warning light is not illuminated, replace the warning light relay. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 18, Figure 19, and Figure 20.

svcsubproc.title: Inspection for Illuminated LEDS - 1

step1.para: Inspect the EC-15 for presence of illuminated LEDs and record on the TROUBLESHOOTING SHEET.
Note the condition of the Green, VOLT LED and:

step2.para: If the green LED is NOT ILLUMINATED, go to step 3.
If the green LED is FLASHING, perform "TESTING FOR POWER TO EC-15."
If the green LED is ILLUMINATED and not flashing, go to step 4.

step1.para: Check the EC-15 for illuminated RED LEDs.

step2.para: If NO RED LEDs are illuminated, perform "TESTING FOR POWER TO EC-15."
If ANY RED LEDs are illuminated, replace the EC-15.

step1.para: Note and RECORD condition of all RED LEDs and:

step2.para: If NO RED LEDs are illuminated, proceed to "TESTING FOR FALSE FAILURE INDICATION - CAUSED BY DASH LAMP RELAY."
If any RED LEDs are illuminated, proceed to "INSPECTION FOR ILLUMINATED LEDS- 3."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 21.

svcsubproc.title: Inspection for Illuminated LEDS - 2

step1.para: Inspect the EC-15 for presence of illuminated LED's and record on the TROUBLESHOOTING SHEET.
Note the condition of the Green, VOLT LED and:

step2.para: If the green LED is NOT ILLUMINATED, go to step 3.
If the green LED is FLASHING, perform "TESTING FOR POWER TO EC-15."
If the green LED is ILLUMINATED and not flashing, go to step 4.

step1.para: Check the EC-15 for illuminated RED LEDs.

step2.para: If NO RED LEDs are illuminated, perform "TESTING FOR POWER TO EC-15.
If ANY RED LEDs are illuminated, replace the EC-15.

step1.para: Note and RECORD condition of all RED LEDs and:

step2.para: If NO RED LEDs are illuminated, proceed to "TESTING FOR FALSE FAILURE INDICATION - CAUSED BY DASH LAMP RELAY."
If any RED LEDs are illuminated, proceed to "INSPECTION FOR ILLUMINATED LEDs - 3."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 22.

svcsubproc.title: Inspection for Illuminated LEDS - 3

step1.para: Note the Red "ECU" LED in the EC-15 diagnostics window. If it is ILLUMINATED, proceed to "Testing For Power To The EC-15." If the ECU LED is NOT ILLUMINATED, proceed to step 2.
There must be a MINIMUM OF THREE RED LEDs ILLUMINATED and of the three, there must be:

step2.para: Either a "RIGHT" or "LEFT" plus
Either a "FRONT" or "REAR" plus
Either a "MOD" or "SENS".

step1.para: If there are less than 3 RED LEDs illuminated and/or there is not one LED from each pair above, then replace the EC-15 and repeat the "Initial Start-up Procedure," otherwise proceed to step 3.
Make note of the three illuminated LEDs on the TROUBLESHOOTING RECORD SHEET.

step2.para: If the "MOD" LED is illuminated along with the two positioning LEDs ("RIGHT" or "LEFT," plus "FRONT" or "REAR") proceed to "Testing The Modulator."
If the "SENS" LED is illuminated along with the two positioning LEDs ("RIGHT" or "LEFT" plus "FRONT" or "REAR") proceed to "Testing The Wheel Speed Sensor."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 23.

svcsubproc.title: Testing for Power to the EC-15

important.para: Vehicle batteries must be fully charged to perform this test. Check batteries for state-of-charge (Refer to GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL). If not fully charged (checked less than 12.60 volts), correct low charge condition before proceeding.

note.para: Record ALL test steps and results on the Troubleshooting Record Sheet.

svcsubproc.para: This test is for 96/9700 and 93/9400 model vehicles. Refer to the circuit diagram for the vehicle being tested. References to particular connector numbers, circuit numbers, etc. will be for the 96/9700 models with the 93/9400 model in parentheses if the number is different. For example: "Disconnect harness connector C355 (or C288)...." The C355 refers to 96/9700 models and C288 refers to the same actual connector on a 93/9400 model, but is numbered differently.

step1.para: Check condition of 30 amp in-line fuse (between circuit 94 and 94K).

step2.para: If fuse is defective, locate cause of the overload condition and repair, then replace the fuse. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If the fuse is not defective, verify that battery voltage is present at the fuse. Then go to step 2.

note.para: Always make certain the key switch is in the OFF position before disconnecting any antilock system electrical connectors. Disconnecting a connector without the key OFF will cause the EC-15 to record "open circuit" faults in the system memory.

step1.para: With the key switch in the OFF position, disconnect wire harness connector C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 controller harness. All circuit tests will be made using the antilock chassis harness connector end and not the EC-15 controller harness end. Turn the vehicle key switch ON and measure the voltage between the ignition feed, circuit 94L (pin J) and ground circuit 94-G (pin P) at the chassis wire harness connector (not EC-15 harness). The voltage should be the same as battery voltage and must be between 11 and 17 volts.

step2.para: If battery voltage is present, use magnet and reset the EC-15, then note the condition of the GREEN LED.

step3.para: If the green LED is flashing, replace the EC-15 controller.
If the green LED is not flashing, run the "Initial Startup Procedure".

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present (either zero volts or less than battery voltage), go to step 3.

step1.para: With the key ON and chassis antilock harness C355 (or C288) disconnected from the EC-15 harness, check voltage to vehicle ground at chassis antilock connector C355 (or C288), circuit 94L (pin J).

step2.para: If battery voltage is present, locate open or high resistance condition (loose connection, damaged wire, etc.) in ground circuit 94-G, then repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If battery voltage is not present, go to step 4.

step1.para: With key ON, check voltage to ground at cab to chassis antilock connector C356 (or C282) at circuit 94A (or 94K) of the cab harness side.

step2.para: If battery voltage is present, locate the open or high resistance condition in circuit 94A/94L between the cab connector C356 (or C282) and C355 (or C288), then repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If battery voltage is not present (either zero volts or less than battery voltage) go to step 5.

step1.para: With key OFF, remove the crank relay from the cab antilock cab harness connector C369 (or C284). Turn the key ON and check voltage to ground at relay harness connector circuit 94K (or 94A). (Circuit 94K (or 94A) is shown at terminal 1 in the circuit diagram.)

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, locate open or high resistance condition in feed circuit, then repair. When defect is corrected go to step 6.
If battery voltage is present, go to step 6.

step1.para: With key ON (NOT START POSITION), check voltage to ground at relay harness connector at circuit 94L. (Circuit 94L is shown at terminal 2 in the circuit diagram.)

step2.para: Voltage should only be present when the cranking motor is engaged. Locate the wiring defect or short to "hot" circuit, then repair. Go to step 7 when defect is corrected.
If voltage is not present, go to step 7.

step1.para: Turn key OFF and use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at relay harness connector circuit 94-GA.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, locate open condition and repair. Then go to step 8.
If continuity to ground is present, go to step 8.

step1.para: At the crank relay harness connector, install a jumper between terminal 3 (circuit 94A (or 94K) and terminal 5 (circuit 94-GA). With the key OFF, at chassis antilock harness connector C355 (or C288), check continuity to ground at circuit 94L (pin J).

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, go to step 9.
If continuity to ground is present, go to step 10.

step1.para: Disconnect the cab to chassis antilock harness connector C356 (or C282) and at the cab side of the connector, check circuit 94A (or 94K) for continuity to ground.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, locate the open in circuit 94A (or 94K) between C356 (or C282) and the crank relay harness connector C369 (or C284), then repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If continuity to ground is present, locate the open in circuit 94L/94A between C356 (or C282) and C355 (or C288), then repair. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step1.para: Re-install the crank relay and with the key ON, measure voltage between circuit 94L (pin J) and circuit 94-G (pin P) at the antilock chassis harness connector C355 (or C288).

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, replace the crank relay. Run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."
If battery voltage is present, the battery power to the EC-15 is verified, as is the ground path.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 24, Figure 25, Figure 26, and Figure 27.

important.para: This test is for 96/9700 and 93/9400 model vehicles. References to a particular connector, circuit, etc. by number, will be made for the 96/9700 models with the 93/9400 model corresponding number in parentheses if the number is different. For example: Disconnect harness connector C355 (or C288)." The C355 refers to the 96/9700 models and the C288 refers to the 93/9400 models.
Vehicle batteries must be fully charged to perform this test. Check batteries for state-of-charge. If not fully charged (less than 12.60 volts), correct condition.

figure.caption: Figure 24. Testing for Power to the EC-15 (Part 1)
Figure 25. Testing for Power to the EC-15 (Part 2)
Figure 26. Testing for Power to the EC-15 (Part 3)
Figure 27. Testing for Power to the EC-15 (Part 4)

svcsubproc.title: Testing the Modulator

note.para: Record LEDs that are illuminated before starting the test. Also record ALL test steps and results on the Troubleshooting Record Sheet.

svcsubproc.para: This test is for 96/9700 and 93/9400 model vehicles. Refer to the circuit diagram for the vehicle being tested. References to particular connector numbers, circuit numbers, etc. will be for the 96/9700 models with the 93/9400 model in parentheses if the number is different. For example: "Disconnect harness connector C355 (or C288)...." The C355 refers to 96/9700 models and C288 refers to the same actual connector on a 93/9400 model, but is numbered differently.

step1.para: Turn the vehicle ignition key switch OFF and disconnect the chassis antilock brake harness connector from the EC-15 harness as explained in steps A and B.

step2.para: To test the left or right front modulator, disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 harness.
To test the left or right rear modulator, disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C350 (with 96/9700 or 93/9400) from the EC-15 harness.

svcsubproc.para: To perform step 2, refer to the circuit diagram and note that each antilock brake modulator has three circuits: a HOLD circuit, a SOURCE circuit and an EXHAUST circuit. The front modulator circuits connect to the EC-15 through connector C355 (or C288). The rear modulator circuits connect to the EC-15 through connector C350 (96/9700 and 93/9400).

Refer again to the circuit diagram for the specific circuit number and pin location for the specific brake modulator to be tested. This test measures the resistance of the solenoid coils (two are contained in each modulator) and tests each modulator circuit (there are three) for any short to ground or short to a battery source. An ohmmeter is used to measure the resistance values between the test points listed in the following chart. The resistance values specified in the chart are for the M-21 modulator. The following example walks you through a brief test for point "A" in the chart.

EXAMPLE: To test the LEFT FRONT MODULATOR on a 9600 model vehicle, turn the key switch OFF and disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C355 from the EC-15 harness. The test will be performed on the antilock chassis harness connector end (not the EC-15 end). Use an ohmmeter to measure resistance between: HOLD (circuit 94AS at pin E) and SOURCE (circuit 97AR at pin M). This measures resistance between point B and point C as shown in the modulator in the circuit diagram. If the coil is not defective, the resistance will be 3.5 to 5.0 ohms. The other points are tested in the same manner.

step1.para: With the switch key OFF, use an ohmmeter to measure the resistance at each test point in the following chart for each modulator to be tested. Record all measurements on the Troubleshooting Record Sheet.

step2.para: If the resistance readings are correct (as shown in the chart) proceed to step 3.
If the resistance readings are not within the specifications, skip step 3 and go to step 4.

step1.para: With the key OFF, inspect the connector, then re-connect to the EC-15. Turn the key ON and reset the EC-15 by passing a magnet over the RESET on the EC-15. Note the reaction of the RED LEDs after resetting.

step2.para: If NONE of the RED LEDs are illuminated, repeat the "Initial Start-up Procedure." If after the "Initial Start-up Procedure" the same LEDs are illuminated (if this step has been repeated two times), replace the EC-15.
If DIFFERENT RED LEDs are illuminated, return to "Inspection For Illuminated Red LEDs" and retest.
If the SAME RED LEDs are illuminated AND it is one of the FRONT MODULATORS being tested, then TEST THE REAR MODULATOR ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE VEHICLE BY RETURNING TO STEP 1.

step3.para: If failure persists, replace the EC-15.

step1.para: Move to the suspected modulator and inspect the wiring and connector for clean, secure connections and no cut or damaged wires.

step2.para: If defects are present, correct and perform step 2 again.
If wiring and connections are good, go to step 5.

step1.para: Refer to the circuit diagram for the modulator connector number and locate the connector composite. The composite provides the pin/circuit information for the connector. Disconnect the antilock chassis harness connector from the modulator. Use ohmmeter to measure the resistance between the pins on the modulator as shown in the following chart. The resistance values listed in the chart are for the M-21 modulator.

EXAMPLE: To test the right rear modulator valve on a 9600 model, refer to the 96/9700 CIRCUIT DIAGRAM for the connector number. Then locate the connector number in the CONNECTOR COMPOSITE. Use the ohmmeter to measure resistance between HOLD (circuit 94AJ attaches) and SOURCE (circuit 94AH attaches). Resistance should read 3.5 to 5 ohms. Measure the resistance at the other test points as indicated in the following chart.

svcsubproc.para: If the resistance readings are as specified in the chart, proceed to step 6, if not, replace the modulator.

step1.para: Reconnect the harness connector to the modulator. Turn the ignition ON and reset the EC-15 by passing a magnet over the RESET on the EC-15. Note the reaction of the RED LEDs.

step2.para: If NONE of the RED LEDs are illuminated, repeat the "Initial Start-up Procedure." If after the "Initial Start-up Procedure" the same LEDs are illuminated (if this step has been repeated two times), replace the EC-15.
If the SAME RED LEDs are illuminated, replace the EC-15 controller.
If DIFFERENT RED LEDs are illuminated, return to "Inspection For Illuminated Red LEDs" and retest.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 28, Figure 29, Figure 30, Figure 31, and Figure 32.

svcsubproc.title: Testing the Wheel Sensor
svcsubproc.para: If during performance of "Inspection For Illuminated LEDs - 3," the SENS RED LED is illuminated, and either the FRONT or REAR LED is illuminated and either a RIGHT or LEFT LED is illuminated, then this test is to be performed.

step1.para: Turn the key switch ON, and make note of which LEDs are illuminated. Reset the EC-15 by passing a magnet over the RESET in the Diagnostic window. Note the reaction of the RED LEDs.

step2.para: If no RED LEDs are illuminated, proceed to step 2.
If the SAME RED LEDs are illuminated, go to step 7.
If DIFFERENT RED LEDs are illuminated (than before resetting), return to "Inspection For Illuminated Red LEDs-3" and retest.

note.para: For the following tests, refer to the circuit diagram for the vehicle being tested to identify circuits and connectors referred to in the test steps.

step1.para: To check resistance of a FRONT sensor, turn the key switch OFF and disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 harness. Use ohmmeter to measure resistance between "input" pin and the "output" pin at connector C355 (or C288) for the sensor being tested. The resistance for the wheel speed sensor should be between 1500-2500 ohms.

To check resistance of a REAR sensor, turn the key switch OFF, and disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C350 from the EC-15 harness. Use ohmmeter to measure resistance between "input" pin and "output" pin at connector C350 for the sensor being tested. The resistance should be between 1500-2500 ohms.

EXAMPLE: To measure resistance of a right front sensor on a 9600 model vehicle, use ohmmeter to measure resistance between circuit 94AU (pin L) and circuit 94AT (pin H) at connector C355, on the chassis antilock harness side of the connector. Tests are not to be made "into" the EC-15.

step2.para: If the sensor resistance is not 1500-2500 ohms, go to step 3.
If the sensor resistance is 1500-2500 ohms, go to step 4.

step1.para: Disconnect the suspect sensor pigtail connector (two pin connector) from the antilock chassis harness. Inspect the connector and visible part of the sensor lead, then check the resistance between the input terminal and the output terminal on the sensor pigtail connector.

step2.para: If the resistance is not 1500-2500 ohms, replace the sensor and reconnect all harnesses. Turn the key ON, and reset the EC-15. Turn key OFF, and back ON to run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

If sensor resistance is 1500-2500 ohms, locate the defect in the chassis antilock harness causing the resistance to be out of specifications and repair. Reconnect all harnesses. Turn the key ON, and reset the EC-15. Turn key OFF, and back ON to run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step1.para: Adjust the sensor gap by pushing the sensor in as far as it will go. Estimate if the sensor moved more than 0.025". For sensor adjustment refer to "Exciter Ring/Sensor Installation" located in this section.
Check and note wheel bearing end play. If end play is more than 0.005", adjust.

step2.para: If the sensor gap or bearing end play was out of specified limits, run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step3.para: If after running the "Initial Start-up Procedure" the SAME LEDs are illuminated, go to step 5.
If after running the "Initial Start-up Procedure" different LEDs are illuminated, proceed to "Inspection For Illuminated LEDs - 1."

step2.para: If the sensor gap and bearing end play were not out of specified limits, go to step 5.

step1.para: Refer to "Exciter Ring/Sensor Installation." Inspect exciter ring for damage and runout, and inspect the sensor for damage and proper gap to exciter ring. Correct any defects. After reconnecting all electrical connections, turn key ON and reset the EC-15 by passing a magnet over the RESET in the LED window. Turn key OFF, then turn key ON and run the "Initial Start-up Procedure." If the "Initial Start-up Procedure" is unsuccessful, note condition of the LEDs.

step2.para: If different LEDs are illuminated, perform "Inspection For Illuminated LEDs - 1."
If the SAME LEDs are illuminated, go to step 6.

step1.para: Replace the suspect sensor, then turn key on and reset the EC-15. Turn key OFF and then turn key ON and run "Initial Start-up Procedure." If the "Initial Start-up Procedure" is again unsuccessful, note condition of the LEDs.

step2.para: If different LEDs are illuminated, perform "Inspection For Illuminated LEDs - 1."
If the SAME LEDs are illuminated, replace the EC-15 controller. Reset the LEDs and rerun the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step1.para: To check resistance of a FRONT sensor, turn the key switch OFF and disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 harness. Use ohmmeter to measure resistance between "input" pin and the "output" pin at connector C355 (or C288) for the sensor being tested. The resistance for the wheel speed sensor should be between 1500-2500 ohms.

To check resistance of a REAR sensor, turn the key switch OFF, and disconnect chassis antilock harness connector C350 from the EC-15 harness. Use ohmmeter to measure resistance between "input" pin and "output" pin at connector C350 for the sensor being tested. The resistance should be between 1500-2500 ohms.

EXAMPLE: To measure resistance of a right front sensor on a 9600 model vehicle, use ohmmeter to measure resistance between circuit 94AU (pin L) and circuit 94AT (pin H) at connector C355, on the chassis antilock harness side of the connector. Tests are not to be made "into" the EC-15.

step2.para: If the sensor resistance is not 1500-2500 ohms, go to step 8.
If the sensor resistance is 1500-2500 ohms, replace the EC-15 controller and run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step1.para: Disconnect the suspect sensor pigtail connector (two pin connector) from the antilock chassis harness. Inspect the connector and visible part of the sensor lead, then check the resistance between the input terminal and the output terminal on the sensor pigtail connector.

step2.para: If the resistance is not 1500-2500 ohms, replace the sensor and reconnect all harnesses. Turn the key ON, and reset the EC-15. Turn key OFF, and back ON to run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

If sensor resistance is 1500-2500 ohms, locate the defect in the chassis antilock harness causing the resistance to be out of specifications and repair. Reconnect all harnesses. Turn the key ON, and reset the EC-15. Turn key OFF, and back ON to run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 33, Figure 34, and Figure 35.

svcsubproc.title: Testing for False Failure Indication - Caused by Dash Light Relay
svcsubproc.para: This test is performed when the yellow antilock warning light located on the instrument panel is illuminated indicating a system defect, but no red LEDs are illuminated on the EC-15 controller.

step1.para: Test the EC-15 LEDs by turning the ignition key ON and holding a magnet on the RESET of the EC-15 diagnostic window, then note that all LEDs should be illuminated while the magnet is in place.

step2.para: If all the LEDs are not illuminated during the reset, replace the EC-15 controller.
If all LEDs illuminate during the reset, go to step 2.

step1.para: Remove the magnet and turn the ignition key OFF. Disconnect the chassis antilock harness at connector C355 (or C288) from the EC-15 harness. Turn the key to the ON position and note the yellow antilock warning light on the instrument panel.

step2.para: If the warning light is not illuminated, replace the EC-15 controller.
If the warning light is still illuminated, do not reconnect the chassis harness to the EC-15 harness at this time, but go to step 3.

step1.para: With the key switch OFF, remove the warning light relay from the antilock cab harness connector C361 (or C285). Use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at the harness relay connector terminal for circuit 94E. Continuity should not be present.

step2.para: If continuity is present, locate the short to ground in circuit 94E and repair. Go to step 4.
If continuity is not present, go to step 4.

step1.para: With the warning light relay removed and the key switch OFF, use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at the relay harness connector for circuit 94-G.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present at circuit 94-G, locate the open in circuit 94-G and repair. Then go to step 5.
If circuit 94-G has continuity to ground, go to Step 5.

step1.para: Use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at circuit 94H or C361 (or C285). There should not be continuity to ground with C355 (or C288) disconnected.

step2.para: If continuity to ground is present, locate the short to ground and repair. Go to step 6.
If continuity to ground is not present, go to step 6.

step1.para: Turn key ON and check voltage to ground at circuit 94B/94C at C361 (or C285).

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, locate open or high resistance condition in circuit 94B and repair. Go to step 7.
If battery voltage is present, go to step 7.

step1.para: Turn key OFF and install jumper between circuits 94-G and 94H at C361 (or C285). Then at connector C355 (or C288) use ohmmeter to check continuity to ground at circuit 94H (pin K).

step2.para: If continuity to ground is not present, locate open condition in circuit 94H and repair. Go to step 8.
If continuity to ground is present, go to step 8.

step1.para: Remove jumper from previous step and re-install warning light relay. Turn key ON and jumper circuit 94H (pin K) at C355 (or C288) to vehicle ground. Note operation of warning light on instrument panel.

step2.para: If light remains illuminated with jumper to ground installed, replace the relay.

If the light is not illuminated when the jumper to ground is complete, reconnect C355 (or C288) to the EC-15 harness. Turn key ON and reset the EC-15 LEDs. Turn key OFF and then ON and run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 36 and Figure 37.
This test is performed when the yellow antilock warning light located on the instrument panel is illuminated, indicating a system defect, but NO RED LEDs are illuminated.

figure.caption: Figure 36. Testing for False Indication - Caused by Dash Light Relay (Part 1)
Figure 37. Testing for False Indication - Caused by Dash Light Relay (Part 2)

svcsubproc.title: Testing For False Failure Indication - Caused By Wheel Speed Components

step1.para: Hold a magnet on the RESET of the EC-15 diagnostic window and note that ALL LEDs are illuminated while the magnet is in place.

step2.para: If all the LEDs ARE NOT ILLUMINATED, replace the EC-15.
If all LEDs are illuminated, go to step 2.

step1.para: Remove the magnet from the EC-15, turn the ignition key to OFF, and inspect the appropriate axle and wheel for the presence of an exciter ring and speed sensor. Check the "gap" (distance between the sensor and the exciter ring) and push sensor in as far as it will go.
Run the vehicle at 10 mph or faster for 30 seconds or more. Turn off the power, then repeat the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 38.

figure.caption: Figure 38. Testing for False Failure Indication - Caused by Wheel Speed Components

svcsubproc.title: Testing ABS/Engine Brake Disable Circuits
svcsubproc.para: With an engine brake and the ABS system installed on a vehicle, whenever the ABS system detects impending wheel lockup, the EC-15 will turn the engine brake off and modulate brake service brake application. When the antilock system stops modulating the service brakes, the engine brake will be back in operation.
Refer to Circuit Diagram.

The engine brake system is controlled by the Engine Brake Relay C361 (or C286), that is part of the ABS cab harness. Power is delivered to the engine brake relay whenever the key is in the ON position on circuit 94E. Note that the relay is normally closed with the switch between relay terminals 1 and 3 closed. Voltage is delivered to the engine brake system on circuit 24E when the key is ON. When the EC-15 determines that a wheel is about to enter a lockup condition, the ground switch in the EC-15 closes and grounds (circuit 94J) the C361 relay control coil, energizing the relay and opening the circuit feeding the engine brake system, disabling the engine brake operation.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Relay - Test 1
svcsubproc.para: This test will be performed if, during the "Initial Startup Procedure" (step 6), the engine brake relay does not "chatter."

step1.para: Refer to the "DIAGNOSING THE INITIAL START-UP TEST PROCEDURE." Notice in step 6 that during the test procedure, the engine brake relay will energize 5 or 6 times, making a "chattering" sound. With engine brake OFF, run the "Initial Startup Procedure" and listen for the chattering of the engine brake relay.

step2.para: If the relay chatters, it would indicate that the relay is functioning properly.
If the relay did not chatter, go to step 2.

step1.para: Remove and replace the relay with known good relay. Then run the "Initial Start-up Procedure."

step2.para: If the relay chatters, it would indicate that the relay is functioning properly.
If the relay did not chatter, go to step 3.

step1.para: Remove the engine brake relay from harness connector C361 (or C286). With key ON, check voltage to ground at relay control coil feed circuit, 94C of C361 (or C286).

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, locate defect in feed circuit 94C, then repair.
If battery voltage is present, go to step 4.

step1.para: Re-install the relay in C361 (or C286), then remove circuit 94J from C355 (or C288) on the chassis side of the connector. With key ON, check voltage to ground at Circuit 94J.

step2.para: If voltage is present, verify that the relay is not defective. If not defective, replace the EC-15 controller.
If voltage is not present, locate the open/short condition in circuit 94J between connectors C361 (or C286) and C355 (or C288), then repair.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 39.

svcsubproc.title: Engine Brake Test 2
svcsubproc.para: Engine brake does not operate. This test determines if the ABS engine brake relay is providing voltage to the Engine Brake System. If voltage is being delivered, and the Engine Brake System does not operate, then the problem is not with the ABS circuits, but in the Engine Brake Circuit. Refer to GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL for troubleshooting information.

step1.para: Replace the engine brake relay C361 (or C286) with another like relay from a different location and retry the engine brake operation. If it still does not operate, go to step 2.
With the key ON, check voltage at connection where either:
circuit 24E (with 96/9700 model) OR
circuit 24A (with 93/9400 models w/electronic engine) OR
circuit 24 (with 93/9400 models w/o electronic engines)
of the ABS cab harness connects to the primary cab harness. See following table for the circuit number of primary cab harness circuit connecting to circuit 24E of the ABS cab harness.

step2.para: If battery voltage is present, the ABS engine brake relay is operating properly, delivering voltage to the engine brake system.
If battery voltage is not present, go to step 3.

para.emph: CONNECTS TO PRIMARY CAB HARNESS CIRCUIT/ENGINE INFO

entry.para: 24E with CAT 3406B N/PEEC & CUMMINS 91L10 STC & 91N14 STC
13B/24 with CAT 3406B N/PEEC & CUMMINS 91L10 STC AND 91N14 STC

step1.para: With the key ON, check the voltage to ground at C361 (or C286) harness connector at circuit 24E (96/9700) or 24A (93/9400 w/ electronic engine) or 24 (93/9400 n/ electronic engine).

step2.para: If battery voltage is not present, locate the open condition in circuit 24E, then repair.
If battery voltage is present, go to step 4.

step1.para: With the key ON, check voltage at C361 (or C286) at circuits 94C/94F and 94F. (NOTE: With a 93/9400 model with an electronic engine, check circuits 94C and 24.)

step2.para: If voltage is not present at circuits identified in step 4, locate the open condition in the feed circuit, then repair.
If voltage is present at feed circuits identified in step 4, go to step 5.

step1.para: Remove circuit 94J from connector C361 (or C286), with key ON check for voltage at circuit 24E at C361.

step2.para: If voltage is not present, replace the relay.
If voltage is present at 24E, go to step 6.

step1.para: With key OFF and circuit 94J removed from C361 (or C286), remove circuit 94J from terminal "B" at at chassis side of C355 (or C288) connector. Then use ohmmeter and check circuit 94J for continuity to ground.

step2.para: If 94J has continuity to ground, locate the short to ground then repair.
If circuit 94J is not shorted to ground, replace the EC-15 controller.

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 40.

svcsubproc.title: Exciter Ring/Wheel Sensor: Adjustment
svcsubproc.para: To adjust the wheel sensors, push the sensor into the bushing (on front axle) or into the mounting block (rear axle) as far as it will go. The sensor will bottom out against the exciter ring, then as the exciter ring rotates, the sensor will self-adjust. To adjust or check adjustment of the rear wheel sensor, the brake drum must be removed.

step1.para: The front axle sensor can be removed from the axle side of the steering knuckle by pulling the sensor out. Inspect the sensor lead, the connector and the sensor for damage. Replace if damaged. To install, push the sensor into the bushing as far as it will go.

The rear axle sensor removal requires that the wheels and brake drum first be removed. Inspect the sensor lead, the connector and the sensor for damage. Replace if damaged. To install, push the sensor into the bushing as far as it will go.

Inspect the exciter rings for damage by removing the brake drum from the wheel hub. If damaged, the exciter ring should be replaced. Observe the exciter ring, noting that it is properly seated on the wheel hub. To inspect for exciter ring runout with respect to the installed sensor, (with drum removed) push the sensor in against the exciter ring. Using a feeler gauge, slowly rotate the wheel hub observing the clearance between the exciter ring and the sensor. The gap must be between 0 and 0.025 inch for proper signal output.

svcsubproc.title: Exciter Ring/Wheel Sensor: Remove and Install

step1.para: Exciter Ring - To remove the exciter ring, first remove the brake drum from the wheel hub. Then remove the hub from the vehicle. Using a suitable puller, lightly heat the exciter ring to expand it and remove from wheel assembly.

To install the exciter ring on the wheel, uniformly heat soak the exciter ring to a temperature of approximately 200 degrees Fahrenheit. It is recommended that the exciter ring be heated by placing it in a 200-degree-Fahrenheit (approximate) bath (water or oil) until the desired temperature is achieved. Then install the exciter ring onto the wheel hub, taking care to fully seat the exciter ring, then allow the exciter ring to cool and "shrink fit" on the wheel hub. Do not heat with a torch as the exciter ring may develop hot spots, causing the exciter ring to distort.

Install the hub to the axle (less the brake drum) and adjust the wheel bearings (refer to SERVICE MANUAL, Group 17). The bearing end play should not exceed .005 inch. Install the sensor and then inspect for runout as described in step 3 of "Inspection." Install the brake drum after the inspection is complete.

Sensor Retainers - To replace the sensor retainer, remove old retainer and insert new retainer from axle side. Push into sensor bushing (front axle) or into sensor mounting block (rear axle) until retainer tongues are against the sensor bushing or mounting block.

figure.caption: Figure 41. Typical Front Axle, Wheel Sensor Installation

calloutgroup.callout1: 4. SENSOR ASSEMBLY INCLUDES LEAD (CONNECTS TO CHASSIS ANTILOCK HARNESS)

step1.para: Front Sensor - Install the sensor into the retainer and sensor bushing from the backside of the steering knuckle. Push the sensor as far as possible through the sensor bushing. Refer to Figure 41. No further adjustment is necessary.

Rear Sensor - Install the sensor into retainer and sensor mounting block from the axle side in a horizontal position with the "cable end" of the sensor positioned as shown in Figure 42 or Figure 43, depending on suspension type. Push the sensor in as far as possible through the mounting block. No further adjustment is necessary.

figure.caption: Figure 42. Typical Rear Sensor Installation With Air Suspension
Figure 43. Typical Sensor Installation With 4-Spring Suspension
